_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary contains the facility's administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia-related accidents and reduce potential risks.  The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is ammonia.  The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:

	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

	Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

	Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

	Five Year Accident History

	Emergency Response Program

	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following Data Elements sections are also attached from the facilitys registration:

		Section 1:	Registration Information
		Section 2:	Toxics - Worst Case Release
		Section 3:	Toxics - Alternative Release
		Section 4:	Flammables - Worst Case Release (NOT APPLICABLE)
		Section 5:	Flammables - Alternative Release (NOT APPLICABLE)
		Section 6:	Five Year Accident History
		Section 7:	Prevention Program 3 Component 
		Section 8:	Prevention Program 2 Component (NOT APPLICABLE)
		Section 9:	Emergency Response Component
 
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The J&J Snack management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  J&J Snacks California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and safety policies are administered by the Director of EHSS. The Director of EHSS conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversee the entire safety and environmental programs, including the CalARP Program. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The J&J Snack facility is located at 5353 S. Downey Road in Vernon, California, which is located approximately 1.7 miles west of Interstate 710 and approximately 2.2 miles south of Interstate 5. The area immediately surrounding the facilit

y is urban.  The facility was constructed and began operations in 1987.  

The primary business of J&J Snack is to provide refrigeration for the production and storage of bakery items. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 14,418 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance. The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the facility. 

Refrigeration System Description

The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant from liquid to gas and back again. The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the production and storage of bakery items.

The refrigeration process begins with the transfer of liquid ammonia from the Condenser to the Horizontal Pilot/Thermosyphon Receiver (PR-1) which sends high pressure liquid to the Intercooler (INT-1), and Dock Coolers (AU-12 & AU-13). 

The Dock Coolers (AU-12 & AU-13) receive high pressure liquid ammonia from the Pilot/Thermosyphon Receiver (PR-1) and feeds high temperature suction to the Intercooler (INT-2). High stage suction is drawn off the top of the to the Vertical Intercooler (INT-2) and sent to the High Stage Compressors (HS-1 & HS-2) and Compressor (C-6). The Intercooler (INT-2) also receives high pressure liquid ammonia from the Horizontal Pilot/Thermosyphon Receiver (PR-1).

At the -40°F Spiral Freezers, -10°F Freezer Evaporators, and +40°F Dock Cooler Evaporators the liquid ammonia, flowing through coils in the unit, is partially boiled as it absorbs heat fr

om the product and room.  The resulting wet suction (liquid/vapor mix) flows to the -40°F Vertical Recirculator (VPR-1), -20°F Vertical Recirculator (VPR-2), and Vertical Intercooler (INT-2) (from the -40°F Spiral Freezers, -10°F Freezer Evaporators, and +40°F Dock Evaporators respectively).   The -40°F Spiral Freezers and -10°F Freezer Evaporators utilize high stage discharge from the compressors for coil defrost. The +40°F Dock Evaporators are operated at higher temperatures and use air to defrost the coils if necessary.

At the Vertical Recirculators (VPR-1 and VPR-2) vapor is drawn off the top of the vessel by the Booster Compressors (from VPR-1) and Single Stage Compressor #6 (from VPR-2). The liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel (VPR-2) and is sent to the other Recirculator (VPR-1) as well as the Storage Freezers (AU-5  AU-11) which returns low temperature suction back to the Recirculatos (VPR-2). The liquid that settles at the bottom of Recirculator (VPR-1) is sent to the spiral freezers (SP-2  SP-5) which then returns low temperature suction back to the Recirculator (VPR-1).

The Booster Compressors (B-1  B-4) draw vapor from the -40°F Vertical Recirculator (VPR-1). The Booster Compressors then send the booster discharge to the Vertical Intercooler.

The Vertical Intercooler (INT-2) receives booster discharge from the Booster Compressors and high temperature suction from the +40?F Dock Evaporators.  The liquid makeup is provided by the Pilot/Thermosyphon Receiver (PR-1). The suction absorbs heat from the surrounding high pressure liquid. The resulting high stage suction is drawn from the Vertical Intercooler (INT-2) by the High Stage Compressors (HS-1- HS-2).  The low temperature liquid is transferred from the Vertical Intercooler (INT-2) to the -40°F Vertical Recirculator (VPR-1). 

The High Stage Compressors (HS-1  HS-2) and Compressor (C-6) draw vapor from the Vertical Intercooler (INT-2). The vapor discharged from the Compressors is routed to

the Condensers.  High pressure discharge from the High Stage Compressors is also routed to the Storage and Spiral Freezers, which utilize hot gas for coil defrost.

At the Condensers, water (pumps) and air (fans) are used to condense the high stage discharge into high pressure liquid, which then drains to the Horizontal Pilot/Thermosyphon Receiver to begin the refrigeration cycle again.

The system is also equipped with an Automatic Purger that removes non-condensibles, i.e. air, from the system.

All process equipment and piping are designed according to ASME standards.  All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves which are set to actuate at 150, 250, 300 psig, depending on equipment operating conditions. Most relief valves in the engine room are piped to a common header, which vents to the atmosphere.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the OES California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

Administrative Measures:  The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards including the following:

	IIAR Standard 5-2019, Startup of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Refrigeration Systems
	IIAR Standard 6-2019, Inspection, Testing, and Maintenance of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Refrigeration Systems
	IIAR Standard 7-2019, Developing Operating Procedures for Closed-Circuit Ammonia Refrigeration Systems
	IIAR, A Guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System

The J&J Snack ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the J&J Snack facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  It is important to note that the refrigeration system has

been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from over-pressurization.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The CalARP Program defines accident as the following:

An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the ambient air from a stationary source.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:

	On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (19 CCR 5080.9(a)); or
	Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (19 CCR 5080.9(a)).

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facilitys accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis study (May 14, 2024), there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five  
years (May 2019  May 2024) nor any releases that meet the California-specific criteria above. However, the facility did experience an ammonia release that warranted an internal incident investigation:

	On June 18, 2022, there was a small leak pinhole leak in a spiral freezer #2 packaging that registered 3 ppm in the Engine Room. C&L Refrigeration, the refrigeration contractor, was onsite to braze the system. There were no environmental or safety impacts.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

	save lives;
	minimize and avoid injuries;
	protect the environment

; and
	minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP regulations.  

J&J Snack personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the Director of EHSS. The Director of EHSS will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazard Analysis study performed on May 14, 2024, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the J&J Snack facility located in Vernon, California.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The J&J Snack safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.  Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.  Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.  Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.  Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

Recommendation tracking for the technical studies is included in Volume III, Recommendation Tracking. In coordination with the local Administe

ring Agency, recommendation implementation timelines resulting from the Process Hazard Analysis study (May 2024) will be coordinated with the City of Vernon Health and Environmental Control department for approval.

EXTERNAL EVENTS 

External events were considered during the Hazard Review as any type of catastrophic failure (i.e. line break).  Catastrophic failures are caused by (but are not limited to): vehicular accidents, meteorite impact, missile impact, sabotage, war, and seismic activity. A catastrophic line failure of the ammonia system could result in a line break, which was examined in the Hazard Assessment.
